vi_translation: By the end of August, the patch of grass growing wildly in the middle of Grimmauld Square had withered in the sun to the point of becoming brittle and dull brown. The residents of number twelve were completely invisible to those living in the surrounding houses. The house number twelve itself was also invisible. The Muggles living in Grimmauld Place have long accepted the curious numbering error that places house number eleven right next to house number thirteen.
tr_translation: As August slowly passed, the neglected grass in the middle of Grimmauld Place withered and turned yellow until it crisped in the sun. Neither the residents of Number Twelve nor Number Twelve itself were seen by anyone living in the surrounding houses. The Muggles living in Grimmauld Place had long accepted that the presence of "Number Thirteen" next to "Number Eleven" was a comical mistake.
es_translation: As August progressed, the neglected rectangle of grass in the center of Grimmauld Place withered under the sun until it became dry and brown. The Muggles who lived in the neighboring houses of that square had never seen the occupants of number 12 nor the house itself, but they had long accepted the amusing numbering error, by virtue of which numbers 11 and 13 they were adjacent.

en: And yet the square was now attracting a trickle of visitors who seemed to find the anomaly most intriguing. Barely a day passed without one or two people arriving in Grimmauld Place with no other purpose, or so it seemed, than to lean against the railings facing numbers eleven and thirteen, watching the join between the two houses. The lurkers were never the same two days running, although they all seemed to share a dislike for normal clothing. Most of the Londoners who passed them were used to eccentric dressers and took little notice, though occasionally one of them might glance back, wondering why anyone would wear cloaks in this heat.

vi_translation: Yet that square now attracts a handful of visitors, people who seem to find that abnormality very appealing. It is rare for a day to pass without one or two people coming to Grimmauld Square with the sole purpose (or seemingly with the purpose) of leaning against the iron fence opposite numbers eleven and thirteen, observing the junction between the two houses. These lurkers are different each day, although they all seem to share a common dislike for dressing normally. Most Londoners are accustomed to seeing eccentrically dressed people, so they no longer pay attention when passing by these lurkers, but occasionally someone will glance back, wondering why anyone would wear a cloak in such hot weather.
tr_translation: Nevertheless, the square still attracted a few visitors of curious abnormality. At least one or two people a day came to Grimmauld Place just for this reason, or at least seemed to come for this reason, leaning against the railings with their faces turned towards numbers "Eleven" and "Thirteen" and watching the junction of the two houses. The lurkers were never the same two days in a row, and it seemed that all of them shared a common dislike for proper attire. The majority of passing Londoners saw these as eccentric outfits and glanced briefly before moving on, though sometimes one would wonder why a person would wear such a robe in this heat and turn back for another look.
es_translation: And yet, the square attracted a trickle of visitors who, apparently, found this anomaly most intriguing. Thus, not a day went by without one or two people arriving at Grimmauld Place with the sole purpose (at least apparently) of leaning on the small fence that enclosed the square, in front of numbers 11 and 13, and observing the junction of the two houses. These individuals were never the same, although they all tended to dress in a very peculiar manner. Most Londoners passing by, accustomed to seeing eccentric characters, didn't pay much attention to them, although occasionally a passerby would turn their head and wonder how anyone could think of going out with such a long cloak, given the heat.

Go ne go se ope yo o neng a le mo malatsing a mabedi a a tshwanang, le fa botlhe ba ne ba lebega ba sa rate go apara diaparo tse di tlwaelegileng. en: A swarm of dementors was gliding amongst the trees; he could feel their chill, and he was not sure he would be able to pass safely through it. He had not strength left for a Patronus. He could no longer control his own trembling. It was not, after all, so easy to die. Every second he breathed, the smell of the grass, the cool air on his face, was so precious: To think that people had years and years, time to waste, so much time it dragged, and he was clinging to each second. At the same time he thought that he would not be able to go on, and knew that he must. The long game was ended, the Snitch had been caught, it was time to leave the air. . . .

vi_translation: A group of Dementors was gliding through the trees; it could feel the chilling cold emanating from them, and it was sure it could safely pass through. It no longer had the strength to summon a Patronus. It could no longer control its own shivering. After all, dying wasn't easy. Every second it breathed, the smell of grass, the cool air caressing its face, felt so precious: to think people had so many years and months, and time to waste, so much time to dawdle, while it was clinging to every single second. At the same time, it thought it couldn't go on, it knew it had to go. The long game was over, the Snitch had been caught, it was time to leave the air... The Snitch ball.
tr_translation: A swarm of Dementors was gliding through the trees; Harry could feel the cold they emitted, and he wasn't sure if he could pass through them safely. He no longer had the strength to create a Patronus. Harry could no longer stop himself from trembling. After all this, dying shouldn't be this easy. Every second he breathed, the smell of the grass, the cool air hitting his face, was precious to him: Thinking that people had years and years, so much time to waste, to leave behind, but now he had to cling tightly to every second. At the same time, Harry thought he couldn't go on but knew he had to. The long game was over, the Snitch had been caught, it was time to leave the sky... Snitch.
es_translation: A swarm of dementors was gliding between the trees. Harry felt their cold spreading and doubted he could fight it off. He had no strength left to conjure a Patronus, nor could he control his trembling anymore. After all, dying wasn't that easy. Every breath he took, the smell of grass, the cool breeze on his face... everything took on great value. And to think that people had years and years of life, plenty of time, so much that sometimes it even became a burden; and he, on the other hand, clung to every passing second. He didn't feel capable of continuing, but he knew he had to. That long game had ended, they had caught the snitch, it was time to descend... The snitch.

vi_translation: That year, autumn seemed to arrive suddenly. The morning of the first day of September was crisp like an apple, and as the small family bobbed across the bustling street towards the large, soot-blackened train station, the smoke from car exhausts and the breath of pedestrians shimmered like spider webs in the cold air. Two enormous cages swayed on the luggage-laden trolleys that the parents were pushing; the owls in the cages hooted angrily, and the red-haired little girl trailed behind her brothers, tearfully clinging to her father's arm.
tr_translation: Autumn seemed to have arrived suddenly that year. The morning of the first day of September was crisp and golden like an apple, and as the small family swayed across the roaring road ahead to reach the large sooty station, the exhaust fumes from the cars and the breaths of the pedestrians sparkled in the cold air like spider webs. The mother and father were pushing a cart laden with goods, on top of which were two large, rattling cages; the owls inside the cages hooted solemnly, and the red-haired girl with tearful eyes clung to her father's arm, following her brothers.
es_translation: That year, autumn came early. The first day of September brought a morning as clear and golden as an apple, and as the small family ran across the noisy street towards the enormous and sooty station, the exhaust fumes and the breath of the pedestrians glistened like cobwebs in the cold atmosphere. On top of the two loaded carts that the parents were pushing, two large cages wobbled with respective owls hooting indignantly. A tearful red-haired girl followed her siblings, clinging to her father's arm.
